</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX3351&amp;tpCode=SSA-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester A</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX3351&amp;tpCode=SSB-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester B</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=BEX3351&amp;tpCode=WS-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Winter semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-BEX3351">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester A 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester B 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Winter semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester A 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester B 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Winter semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-peninsula.html">Peninsula</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester A 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Summer semester B 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Winter semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/BEX3350.html">BEX3350</a></span></p>
<p>Enrolment in this unit is subject to an application process. More information on this unit is available <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/business/student-experience/career-development/industry-experience/work-integrated-learning/undergraduate-industry-experience/student-sourced-placements">here</a><span class="hbk-print-url">here (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/business/student-experience/career-development/industry-experience/work-integrated-learning/undergraduate-industry-experience/student-sourced-placements">https://www.monash.edu/business/student-experience/career-development/industry-experience/work-integrated-learning/undergraduate-industry-experience/student-sourced-placements</a>)</span>. Applications must be submitted via this <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="https://www.monash.edu/business/student-experience/career-development/industry-experience/work-integrated-learning/application-and-approval-process">link</a><span class="hbk-print-url">link (<a href="https://www.monash.edu/business/student-experience/career-development/industry-experience/work-integrated-learning/application-and-approval-process">https://www.monash.edu/business/student-experience/career-development/industry-experience/work-integrated-learning/application-and-approval-process</a>)</span>.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in a Faculty of Business and Economics undergraduate program.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is designed to enable students undertaking undergraduate degrees in business and economics to undertake an individual research project in the general area of business.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>demonstrate an ability to apply a broad range of knowledge and understanding of key business theories, concepts, tools and techniques in a practical context</li>
<li>investigate, describe, consider and evaluate a specific business issue</li>
<li>develop higher level business conceptualisations and understandings about the topic under investigation</li>
<li>to report on the outcomes of the project</li>
<li>to reflect and report on the personal learning derived from the project.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS2127</span> - Composition and music technology 3: Spatial composition techniques<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS2127">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-sir-zelman-cowen-school-of-music.html">Sir Zelman Cowen School of Music</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ryan Smith">Dr Ryan Smith</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ryan Smith">Dr Ryan Smith</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=ATS2127&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS2127">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ATS1047.html">ATS1047</a></span> or ATS1350</p>
<p>This unit is only available to students enrolled in a Bachelor of Music single or double degree - Composition and creative music technology specialisation.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>ATS2808</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><ul>
<li>The unit has a compulsory <a class="hbk-screen-url" href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/music/category/performance-studies/student-ensembles/">ensemble component</a><span class="hbk-print-url">ensemble component (<a href="http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/music/category/performance-studies/student-ensembles/">http://artsonline.monash.edu.au/music/category/performance-studies/student-ensembles/</a>)</span>. Some ensembles are subject to audition. Normally, auditions take place in Week 1 of the semester. Please see the unit guide for further information.</li>
<li>Students who fail this unit will need permission from the unit coordinator in order to repeat the unit.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit introduces spatial composition concepts and requires students to create short original compositions that combine acoustic and electronic instruments. Students will also develop skills specific to studio recording and mixing, as well as critical skills relating to these practices.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify spatial composition techniques;</li>
<li>experiment with spatial composition techniques in original works;</li>
<li>record and mix music in a studio;</li>
<li>analyse and reflect on the production process and techniques used in the studio recording;</li>
<li>perform effectively in a chosen/approved music ensemble;</li>
<li>critique compositions, demonstrating perceptive listening skills.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/composition-and-music-technology">Composition and music technology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_ada"><span class="unitcode">AHT2011</span> - Baroque to enlightenment: European art before modernism<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AHT2011">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_ada">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-ada.html">Art, Design and Architecture</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-fine-art.html">Department of Fine Art</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Luke Morgan">Associate Professor Luke Morgan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Luke Morgan">Associate Professor Luke Morgan</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=AHT2011&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AHT2011">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>12 credit points at first year level in Art History &amp; Theory, or Theory of Art &amp; Design, or Visual Culture, or permission from the Unit Coordinator</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AHT3011.html">AHT3011</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit focuses on European art of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Key historical and theoretical topics in the art of the period will be considered, such as: the emphasis in Italian and Spanish Baroque art on spectacle, excess and spirituality; the tradition and legacy of French classicism from Poussin to Ingres; Northern European genre and still-life painting; art as politics and social commentary in France, England and Spain; the emergence of landscape and the philosophy of the picturesque and the sublime; the eroticism and escapism of Rococo; and the phenomenon of Romanticism.</p>
<p>The unit will provide students with an understanding of the history and historiography of European art after the Renaissance and before Modernism. Recent research and current topics of debate will be emphasised in lectures, seminar discussions and readings.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Identify the main characteristics of seventeenth- and eighteenth-century European art;</li>
<li>Understand the historical, cultural and social contexts of seventeenth- and eighteenth-century European art;</li>
<li>Understand key aesthetic, philosophical and historiographical concepts in seventeenth- and eighteenth-century European art;</li>
<li>Perform critical analyses of historical works of art;</li>
<li>Demonstrate a broad knowledge of the history of European art.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>100% in-semester assessment</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>12 hours per week including 3 contact hours plus 9 hours of independent study, or equivalent.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKW2431</span> - Business marketing<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKW2431">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Low Koon Huat">Associate Professor Low Koon Huat</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Low Koon Huat">Associate Professor Low Koon Huat</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKW2431&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKW2431">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKW2402.html">MKW2402</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Topics include the nature and environment of business marketing, buying process in business marketing, marketing intelligence and business market targeting, networking and relationship, planning a business marketing mix strategy, ethical issues in business marketing.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>define and explain the dynamic nature of business marketing</li>
<li>illustrate the organisational buying decision process and the role of buying centre in buying decisions</li>
<li>develop competencies in business marketing strategy components</li>
<li>demonstrate application of marketing theories and concepts in the management of  business marketing functions</li>
<li>critically evaluate the techniques that can be used to assess market opportunities.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>

<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">CPS5008</span> - Principles of working with parents<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CPS5008">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-clinical-sciences-at-monash-health.html">School of Clinical Sciences at Monash Health</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jennifer Re">Dr Jennifer Re</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Nada Lane">Ms Nada Lane</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CPS5008&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CPS5008">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CPS5001.html">CPS5001</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CPS5002.html">CPS5002</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CPS5003.html">CPS5003</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CPS5004.html">CPS5004</a></span> and one of either <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CPS5005.html">CPS5005</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/CPS5006.html">CPS5006</a></span></p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in course code M6022</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit will examine an understanding of the role of parents in their child's development and different ways of working with parents from a psychodynamic and  developmental perspective. Consideration will be made of the following ways of working with parents and the similarities and difference in the models: parent therapy; parent and child work combined; short-term and crisis work with parents; parent counselling; parent education; marital therapy/counselling; individual therapy/counselling.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>critically analyse theoretical and clinical concepts of working with parents;</li>
<li>evaluate the importance of parents' own development as it may affect their role as parents;</li>
<li>explore possible ways of working with parents as relevant to their particular needs and those of their child/children; and</li>
<li>evaluate the difficulties that may be experienced by the therapist when working with parents.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Written assignment 1 (15%)</li>
<li>Written assignment 2 (25%)</li>
<li>Essay (40%)</li>
<li>On-campus workshop / Alternative assessment (20%)</li>
</ul>
<p>All assessments must be passed to pass the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>Two day on-campus workshop.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/psychology">Psychology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGX4300</span> - Contemporary issues in management<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGX4300">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julie Wolfram-Cox">Professor Julie Wolfram-Cox</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Julie Wolfram-Cox">Professor Julie Wolfram-Cox</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGX4300&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGX4300">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Students must be enrolled in course B3701.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Topics selected for emphasis will alter as contemporary issues change. The study of great ideas in management on motivation, job design, human resource management, ethics, social responsibility, leadership, production/operations management, business policy, strategy, and the management process are explored through the study of the works of major management scholars.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify and critically examine a range of contemporary issues in management from a variety of theoretical and practical perspectives</li>
<li>demonstrate a range of relevant scholarship/research skills in acquiring, integrating, interpreting, synthesising, utilising and communicating information about the contemporary issues examined</li>
<li>summarise the major implications of the issues examined as they relate to their own lives and their careers in organisations, the theory and practice of managers and management, and the broader societal and environmental  implications of the issues, both now and into the future</li>
<li>demonstrate skills in written and inter-personal communication including creating effective learning environments for themselves and others.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 70% + Examination: 30%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_eng"><span class="unitcode">TRC4100</span> - Bio-interfacing devices<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-TRC4100">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_eng">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-eng.html">Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-electrical-and-computer-systems-engineering.html">Department of Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Manos Varvarigos">Professor Manos Varvarigos</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=A Senanayake">A Senanayake</a>
        
        (Malaysia)
      
    <br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-TRC4100">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>TRC2400 or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/ECE2071.html">ECE2071</a></span> or <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MEC2407.html">MEC2407</a></span> and 96 credit points and all first level units completed</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Studies from earlier stages of the course are integrated in such a way that students will gain knowledge and skills in the development of movement analysis system. Fundamental devices of bio-electronic devices and phases involved in product development are covered. Bioinstrumentation for measurements of key parameters involved in the use of bio-interfacing devices is addressed based on virtual technologies. Basic elements required for bio-interfacing devices in movement analysis, sensors and vision are considered. In order to downolad acquired data/signals from sensors and vision, specific Data Acquisition (DAQ) methods will be analysed and tested. Students will be taught synchronisation of signals and data as the critical issue. Based on synchronized data signals, movement model reconstruction will be essential in order to understand the motion. Finally, motion regeneration will be created based on the movement data measured and preprocessed.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>After completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>develop prototypes of real time systems for movement analysis</li>
<li>utilise bio-interfacing devices, bio-instrumentation and virtual technologies</li>
<li>incorporate varieties of wired and wireless sensors and different vision technologies, video and optical as fundamental elements for movement analysis</li>
<li>construct bio-interfacing devices using the integration of DAQ modules together with virtual technologies as measurement tools</li>
<li>extract preproprocessed data and signals using interactive Graphical User Interfacing (IGUI) programming to reconstruct movement models</li>
<li>understand the key features and phases involved in motion regeneeration development, testing and simulation in order to represent accurate movement in soft-real time</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Assignments: 30% + Tutorial work: 10% + Examination (3 hours): 60%</p>
<p>Students are required to achieve at least 45% in the total continuous assessment component and at least 45% in the final examination component and an overall mark of 50% to achieve a pass grade in the unit. Students failing to achieve this requirement will be given a maximum of 45% in the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Lectures: 2 hours per week + Laboratory: 3 hours per week + Practice class: 1 hour per week</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">ATS3974</span> - European integration and security<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-ATS3974">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-politics-and-international-relations.html">Politics and International Relations</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ben Wellings">Dr Ben Wellings</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Ben Wellings">Dr Ben Wellings</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-ATS3974">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Twelve credit points of second-year Arts units. It is highly recommended that students only take this unit after they have completed two cornerstone units in Politics or International relations.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>War and security have been crucial motors of international relations, not least in Europe the birthplace of the Westphalian state system. The European Union is commonly seen to have been an antidote to war, ushering in an era of Kantian peace; a view powerfully endorsed by the awarding of the Nobel Prize to the EU in 2012. Despite the strength of this view, recent research suggests it is possible to look at the relationship between peace and European unity differently. In fact, European unity has been propelled by war since 1945: not just at the founding moment at the end of the Second World War (NATO, EEC, WEU), but by anti-colonial nationalists pushing European powers towards pro-active European policies, and in EU responses to the conflicts in the former Yugoslavia (OSCE, CFSP), Iraq, Libya and the challenges posed by refugee movements and global terrorism. An unintended consequence of the logic of deeper integration has been the consolidation of a European identity amongst some elites, whilst political and popular support for the EU has weakened. This last development poses serious questions about the future shape the state system in what remains a major player in regimes of global governance and security.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>identify and appraise the concepts, parameters and architecture of European security in a global context;</li>
<li>distinguish between the concepts of traditional and non-traditional security and recognise the competing paradigms in the security studies literature;</li>
<li>explain and analyse the course and dynamics of European integration since the end of the second World War;</li>
<li>integrate one set of academic literature (European integration theory and history) with another (European security);</li>
<li>undertake a research analysis of an important aspect of European integration or a major security policy area, utilising primary and secondary-source materials with written feedback.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 100%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/international-relations">International relations</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">NUT1011</span> - Human nutrition: An introduction to nutrients<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-NUT1011">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-nutrition-dietetics-and-food.html">Department of Nutrition, Dietetics and Food</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Chiara Murgia">Dr Chiara Murgia</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Elizabeth Barber">Dr Elizabeth Barber</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUT1011&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=NUT1011&amp;tpCode=SSA-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester A</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-NUT1011">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (Online)</li><li>Summer semester A 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in an Undergraduate Degree</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>Unit code: <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/NUT1010.html">NUT1010</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit focuses on basic concepts in human nutrition. It will introduce the concepts of energy balance and body composition and outline the process of digestion. It will describe the role and function of macro and micronutrients essential for human health, their history of discovery, and relevance for the health of populations and individuals.</p>
<p>The dietary recommendations for optimal nutrition for the Australian population will be compared with recommendations in other countries. The unit will include the clinical signs and symptoms of specific nutrient deficiency and excess, as well as nutrient interactions and their significance.</p>
<p>Methods of nutrition assessment will be explored focussing on methods used to assess food intake, data analysis using qualitative and quantitative methods; and comparison of this data to recommended dietary intakes for optimal health.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Explain the process of digestion and absorption of macro and micronutrients and discriminate between their respective role(s) in the human body.</li>
<li>Identify foodsources of particular nutrients, and recognise the clinical signs and symptoms of particular nutrient deficiencies and excesses, and explain the reason for their development.</li>
<li>Describe basic dietary assessment techniques and discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different methods of assessing food intake when evaluating nutritional status.</li>
<li>Explain how food composition data is obtained and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of this data in diet evaluation.</li>
<li>State current nutritional recommendations for the general population and apply them to evaluate the adequacy of diets.</li>
<li>Recognise the effects that nutrients may have on the absorption and utilisation of other nutrients.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Online Quiz (10%)</li>
<li>Assignments (40%) (hurdle)</li>
<li>Exam (2 hours) (50%) (hurdle)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/nutrition">Nutrition</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MKM5955</span> - Marketing and the international consumer<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MKM5955">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-marketing.html">Department of Marketing</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Vicki Janine Little">Dr Vicki Janine Little</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yunus Ali">Associate Professor Md Yunus Ali</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Vicki Janine Little">Dr Vicki Janine Little</a>
        
        (First semester)
      
    <br/>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Yunus Ali">Associate Professor Md Yunus Ali</a>
        
        (Second semester)
      
    <br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKM5955&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MKM5955&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MKM5955">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Evening)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKF5955.html">MKF5955</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKS5955.html">MKS5955</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MKZ5955.html">MKZ5955</a></span>.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Marketing is a means by which organisations create value for their stakeholders within pre-determined objectives. Marketing is widely accepted as a means for delivering greater levels of customer satisfaction, profitability, and sustainability within both a tactical and strategic framework. This unit will prepare graduates for the development, implementation and control processes and procedures of strategic marketing management plans for products and services of an organisation.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>facilitate understanding of the conceptual framework of marketing in value creation and its many applications in decision making under various environmental constraints and with an Asia Pacific focus</li>
<li>evaluate market based information, using it to plan and develop marketing strategies</li>
<li>understand the behaviour of consumers and their role in value creation</li>
<li>understand how value is created using elements of the marketing mix strategies</li>
<li>understand the role of brands in value creation</li>
<li>apply strategic planning tools in developing a marketing mindset.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 50% + Examination: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">MIS4100</span> - Regenerative medicine research project<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">36 points, SCA Band 2, 0.750 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MIS4100">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=James Bourne">Associate Professor James Bourne</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=James Bourne">Associate Professor James Bourne</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MIS4100&amp;tpCode=FY-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Full year</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MIS4100&amp;tpCode=S2-S1-02&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester to First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MIS4100">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Full year 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 to First semester 2020 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in an approved Honours in the discipline of Regenerative medicine</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MIS4200.html">MIS4200</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The Honours year aims to develop analytic abilities, research skills, and communication skills, as well as provide students with advanced knowledge in specific areas of:</p>
<ul>
<li>heart and muscle development and regeneration</li>
<li>immunity and regeneration</li>
<li>stem cells, cancer and regeneration</li>
<li>neural regeneration.</li>
</ul>
<p>In this unit, training is in the context of a scientific project, with an aim to train students in cutting edge scientific techniques as well as developing broad generic skills. Students undertake a supervised research project of a publishable standard that forms the basis of a thesis due at the end of the year. Students will also present seminars on their research throughout the year.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Critically review the scientific literature that underpins the area of the research project;</li>
<li>Undertake a supervised research project and contribute to project design and management;</li>
<li>Apply appropriate laboratory techniques, research methodologies and data analysis methods to collect, interpret and report research findings;</li>
<li>Effectively present research and findings orally showing a firm grasp of the area;</li>
<li>Analyse research undertaken in the context of the discipline area and report findings in an extended written report.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Assessment will be a submission of a research thesis: 85%</p>
<p>Two seminars: 15%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>To be advised by honours co-ordinator</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Regenerative medicine</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_sci"><span class="unitcode">EAE5000</span> - Advanced atmospheric science research project A<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">12 points, SCA Band 2, 0.250 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-EAE5000">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_sci">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-sci.html">Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-earth-atmosphere-and-environment.html">School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael Reeder">Professor Michael Reeder</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Michael Reeder">Professor Michael Reeder</a>
<br/>
</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-EAE5000">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p>Not offered in 2019</p>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Enrolment in the Master of Science</p>
</div>
</div>
<div class="notes">
<p class="hbk-heading hdg_6">Notes</p>
<p></p><p>This unit will be offered annually from Semester 1, 2020</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Students will do a research project in weather, climate or ocean science.  The main relevant areas of research are aerosols (including cloud seeding), boundary layers, climate change, clouds, convection, ENSO, general circulation, synoptic-dynamical meteorology, mesoscale meteorology, numerical modelling, tropical meteorology, and bushfires and fire weather.</p>
<p>In most cases, the project will be a continuation of that completed in <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE4001.html">EAE4001</a></span> but expanded and deepened.  The intention is that the completed project should be suitable for submission for publication in a research journal.</p>
<p>Alternatively, the student may choose a different research project, with the aim of developing a greater breadth of understanding of atmospheric science.  Nonetheless, the student must demonstrate greater research maturity and command of the subject matter than that required for <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/EAE4001.html">EAE4001</a></span>.</p>
<p>The research project may be theoretical, computational or observation-based.  Each student will work under the supervision of at least one of the academic members of staff.  The project will involve a literature review, original research, a written thesis and an oral report on the work.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of this unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Understand, synthesise and summarise the existing literature.</li>
<li>Identify gaps in our knowledge in their chosen area of research.</li>
<li>Advance our knowledge in the chosen area through original research.</li>
<li>Present their findings in a written thesis and oral presentation.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Progress will be assessed through a written progress report: 50% and an oral presentation: 50%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>A total of 24 hours per week.</p>
<p>If the student starts a new project:</p>
<ul>
<li>attendance at a 1-hour seminar</li>
<li>1-hour consultation with the supervisor</li>
<li>10 hours per week of reading and summarising the literature (averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>1 hour per week developing the research plan (averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>10 hours per week of research (averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>1 hour per week writing the progress report (averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>1 hour per week preparing the oral report (averaged over the semester)</li>
</ul>
<p>If the student continues and existing project:</p>
<p>attendance at a 1-hour seminar</p>
<ul>
<li>1-hour consultation with the supervisor</li>
<li>17 hours per week of research (averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>4 hours per week writing the thesis (averaged over the semester)</li>
<li>1 hour per week preparing the oral report (averaged over the semester)</li>
</ul><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p>Master of Science in Atmospheric Science</p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">RAD5201</span> - Emergency image interpretation 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-RAD5201">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-medical-imaging-and-radiation-sciences.html">Department of Medical Imaging and Radiation Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Imelda Williams">Mrs Imelda Williams</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Imelda Williams">Mrs Imelda Williams</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=RAD5201&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-RAD5201">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (Online)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Post graduate students only</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is an elective unit within the Master of Clinical Medicine (Emergency Medicine and Trauma specialisms).</p>
<p>The unit will examine the psychophysics of visual perception and the phenomenon of pattern recognition as a precursor to the development of sound radiographic image interpretation skills.</p>
<p>Students will be provided with opportunities to reinforce their existing knowledge of normal radiographic anatomy including skeletal variants in adults and children.</p>
<p>The unit will specifically develop interpretative skills in the assessment of radiographic images of common conditions affecting the long bones, girdles, cervical spine and chest within the trauma and emergency setting.</p>
<p>The unit will conclude with an introduction to the physical principles underpinning the generation of CT images of the head and neck and develop skills in the interpretation of these images.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Distinguish between sensitivity, specificity and accuracy in relation to the interpretation of radiographic images in the emergency and trauma context.</li>
<li>Critically apply the knowledge of the psychophysics of vision to patterns seen in radiographic images of the long bones, girdles, spine and chest.</li>
<li>Apply a logical method to the accurate interpretation of normal and abnormal radiographic images of the long bones, girdles, spine and chest acquired in the emergency and trauma context.</li>
<li>Generate informed opinions about radiographic images of common conditions affecting the long bones, girdles, cervical spine and chest in the emergency and trauma context.</li>
<li>Differentiate between the various projection modes used to generate multislice CT images of the head and neck.</li>
<li>Accurately distinguish between normal and abnormal appearances on multislice CT images of the head and neck.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Fieldwork</h2>
<div>
<p>Students must be employed in clinical positions within emergency and trauma hospital based contexts with access to medical imaging. </p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Online imaging anatomy analysis and recognition examination (45 minutes) (20%)</li>
<li>1 secure online examination (30 minutes) (15%)</li>
<li>1 x online radiographic image interpretation examination (45 minutes) (20%)</li>
<li>1 x online CT image interpretation examination (45 minutes) (20%)</li>
<li>Completion of a medical image portfolio (25 images and reports) (25%)</li>
</ul>
<p>Hurdle Requirement: Each element of assessment is a hurdle for this unit</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Off-campus, 6 hours teacher directed activities via Moodle learning management system.  6 hours of self-directed study in the clinical workplace.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/medical-ultrasound">Medical ultrasound</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

</nav>
<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_arts"><span class="unitcode">AZA4420</span> - Adult psychopathology<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-AZA4420">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_arts">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-arts.html">Arts</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-south-africa-school-of-social-science.html">South Africa School of Social Science</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Daniella Rafaely">Ms Daniella Rafaely</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Daniella Rafaely">Ms Daniella Rafaely</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=AZA4420&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-AZA4420">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-south-africa.html">South Africa</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AZA4430.html">AZA4430</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AZA4440.html">AZA4440</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AZA4445.html">AZA4445</a></span>, <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/AZA4480.html">AZA4480</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>The unit aims to increase students' understanding of abnormal behaviour through the study of psychological disorders described in the Diagnostic Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders Text Revised (DSMP-IV-TR). Students will be exposed to the major clusters of psychological disorders so that they will be able to recognize the core symptoms of psychological disorders and understand the aetiological factors involved. Through student presentation and class discussion, students will be introduced to a number of current topics and contrasting theories.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of the unit, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Analyse contemporary research, theoretical and applied issues in psychopathology.</li>
<li>Critically appraise current psychopathology literature.</li>
<li>Appraise the role of culture in the expression of psychological disorders.</li>
<li>Comment on historical changes in what is considered abnormal behaviour.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 40% + Exam: 60%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study. A unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/psychology---south-africa">Psychology - South Africa</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_it"><span class="unitcode">FIT5126</span> - Masters thesis part 1<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 2, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-FIT5126">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_it">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-it.html">Information Technology</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Pari Delir Haghighi">Dr Pari Delir Haghighi</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5126&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5126&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=FIT5126&amp;tpCode=SSB-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Summer semester B</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-FIT5126">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>First semester 2019 (Online)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Online)</li><li>Summer semester B 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul><p><a href="index-bylocation-malaysia.html">Malaysia</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (Evening)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (Evening)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p>Admission to an FIT Masters program.</p>
<p>Students must have successfully completed 24 points of level five non-foundation units and have achieved an overall average of at least 75% across all non-foundation units. Foundation units are (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9123.html">FIT9123</a></span> or FIT5123), (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9130.html">FIT9130</a></span> or FIT5130), (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9131.html">FIT9131</a></span> or FIT5131), (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9132.html">FIT9132</a></span> or FIT5132), (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9134.html">FIT9134</a></span> or FIT5134) and (<span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT9135.html">FIT9135</a></span> or FIT5135).</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT5125.html">FIT5125</a></span></p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit is a research unit common to FIT Masters degrees. Due to the nature of IT, a wide range of Masters project types can be offered to students. Some project components are of a practical nature and may involve software development and/or experimentation, while other components are of a more theoretical nature.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>On completion of the Masters thesis, students will be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>design a rigorous Masters level research project and develop project proposal;</li>
<li>critically review research literature, research design and reported findings;</li>
<li>evaluate and select research methods and techniques of data collection and analysis appropriate to particular research designs, projects and disciplines;</li>
<li>conduct ethical research;</li>
<li>communicate research findings in written and oral form in research and industry settings.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit forms part of the sequence of units comprising the Masters Thesis in the Faculty of Information Technology.</p>
<p>The exit point is <span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/FIT5128.html">FIT5128</a></span> (18cpts). At the completion of the requirements for the thesis the following components of assessment will be completed:</p>
<p>Research Proposal: 5%; Literature Review: 10%; Interim Presentation: hurdle; Final Presentation: 5%;Thesis (normally 15,000 - 25,000 words): 80%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload equals 12 hours per week. Students will be expected to hold regular meetings with supervisor(s) over the course of the semester.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_bus"><span class="unitcode">MGF2341</span> - Managing employee relations<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 3, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-MGF2341">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_bus">Undergraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-bus.html">Business and Economics</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-department-of-management.html">Department of Management</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marjorie Jerrard">Dr Marjorie Jerrard</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Marjorie Jerrard">Dr Marjorie Jerrard</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGF2341&amp;tpCode=S1-01&amp;tpYear=2019">First semester</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=MGF2341&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-MGF2341">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-caulfield.html">Caulfield</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>First semester 2019 (On-campus)</li><li>Second semester 2019 (On-campus)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prerequisites</p>
<p><span class="unitlink"><a href="/pubs/2019handbooks/units/MGF1010.html">MGF1010</a></span> or equivalent.</p>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Prohibitions</p>
<p>MGC2410, MGC2420.</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>Management of employment relationships and workplace issues is central to the unit. Roles of parties to the employment relationship -- management, employees, trade unions, employer groups, governments, and tribunals -- are analysed. Management and employee roles in conflict resolution, negotiation and bargaining, conciliation and arbitration, and maintaining control of the employment relationship are covered. External and internal environments are considered regarding productivity, equity, regulation, labour market reform, and decentralisation of the industrial relations system to an enterprise focus.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>The learning goals associated with this unit are to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>differentiate between employee relations issues and industrial relations issues using current research</li>
<li>describe the main institutional features and key developments in the Australian industrial relations system as they impact upon employee relations</li>
<li>identify management strategies for dealing with employee relations in Australian workplaces and those in other countries</li>
<li>participate in individual and team-based analysis of workplace case studies and activities</li>
<li>develop basic skills in managing communication, negotiation, and bargaining at the workplace.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<p>Within semester assessment: 60% + Examination: 40%</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Workload requirements</h2>
<div>
<p>Minimum total expected workload to achieve the learning outcomes for this unit is 144 hours per semester typically comprising a mixture of scheduled learning activities and independent study.  Independent study may include associated readings, assessment and preparation for scheduled activities. The unit requires on average three/four hours of scheduled activities per week. Scheduled activities may include a combination of teacher directed learning, peer directed learning and online engagement.</p><p>See also <a href="http://www.monash.edu.au/timetables/">Unit timetable information</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>

<div class="content-inner__main">

<div class="hbk-banner-box">
<h1 class="banner_med"><span class="unitcode">CMH5004</span> - Recovery oriented mental health practice<span class="hbk-archive-only"> - 2019</span></h1>
</div>
<div id="content_container_">
<h2 class="hbk-eftsl">6 points, SCA Band 1, 0.125 EFTSL</h2>
<div class="hbk-unit-info-box" id="box-CMH5004">
<h2 class="hbk-unit-info-box__heading heading_med">Postgraduate - Unit</h2>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value">Refer to the specific
         <a href="http://monash.edu/enrolments/dates/census.html">census and withdrawal dates</a>
         for the semester(s) in which this unit is offered.</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Faculty</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byfaculty-med.html">Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Organisational Unit</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-value"><a href="index-byou-school-of-clinical-sciences-at-monash-health.html">School of Clinical Sciences at Monash Health</a></p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Chief examiner(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Graham Meadows">Professor Graham Meadows</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Coordinator(s)</p>
<p>
<a href="http://staffsearch.monash.edu/?name=Jill Gray">Ms Jill Gray</a>
<br/>
</p>
<p class="hbk-highlight-heading">Unit guides</p>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="http://unitguidemanager.monash.edu/view?unitCode=CMH5004&amp;tpCode=S2-01&amp;tpYear=2019">Second semester</a>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble " id="preamble-CMH5004">
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<div class="hbk-preamble-icon hbk-preamble-icon_mode"></div>
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Offered</p>
<p><a href="index-bylocation-clayton.html">Clayton</a></p><ul class="hbk-preamble-list__offerings"><li>Second semester 2019 (<a href="index-bymode-off-campus.html">Off-campus</a>)</li></ul>
</div>
<div class="hbk-preamble-entry">
<p class="hbk-preamble-heading">Co-requisites</p>
<p>Must be enrolled in a Postgraduate degree</p>
</div>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Synopsis</h2>
<div>
<p>This unit considers some of the broad issues that are significant in mental health and wellbeing and community mental health practice. The unit will take us beyond the individual explanations of health and ill health to an examination of some of the broad understandings about the courses of mental ill health and the strategies required to improve mental health. We examine the concept of need in relation to populations and take a practical approach to the process of assessing the mental health needs of populations and groups. Two major community intervention strategies to address mental health needs are examined. The role of consumer participation and collaboration and the notion of citizenship are explored in some detail. The unit concludes with a discussion of the skill base required for community mental health practice.</p>
<p>Contents include:</p>
<ul>
<li>The policy context of community mental health practice;</li>
<li>Practice Paradigms;</li>
<li>Community as a place for mental health practice;</li>
<li>The concept of need;</li>
<li>Assessing mental health needs;</li>
<li>Particular groups and the iInterpretation of need;</li>
<li>Community based intervention models and strategies;</li>
<li>Power, participation and collaboration;</li>
<li>Consumers and citizenship.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Outcomes</h2>
<div>
<p>Upon successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:</p>
<ol princestart="0" start="1" type="1">
<li>Describe various practice paradigms and their place in community mental health practice;</li>
<li>Critically analyse the concept of need and competently do a need assessment and develop community intervention models;</li>
<li>Identify and discuss the skills needed for community mental health practice;</li>
<li>Demonstrate a knowledge of the concepts of empowerment, consumer participation and collaborative practices; and</li>
<li>Develop a consumer focused understanding of mental health needs.</li>
</ol>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Assessment</h2>
<div>
<ul>
<li>Hurdle requirement: Participation in a minimum of 5 Moodle discussions</li>
<li>Essay (3,500 words) (60%)</li>
<li>Applied Learning Exercise (1,750 words) (30%)</li>
<li>On-Campus Workshop / Alternate Assessment (10%)</li>
</ul>
<p>All assessments must be passed to pass the unit.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">Off-campus attendance requirements</h2>
<div>
<p></p><p>Two day on-campus workshop.</p>
</div>
<h2 class="hbk-heading">This unit applies to the following area(s) of study</h2>
<div>
<p><a href="../aos/psychology">Psychology</a></p>
</div>
<!-- /.content_container--> </div>
<!-- /.content-inner__main --></div>
